column5: Australia
Yep! Been maintaining six months now.

I love listening to scientist tear apart the PACE trial. Theyâ€™ve hurt so many people and their science is still actively trying to hurt us as the remaining CFS Clinics in my city are all PACE based. Itâ€™s ridiculous. 

I just read theyâ€™re pushing this science into Covid patients and Iâ€™m in a rage.

Oh ffs, they have?!

Why arenâ€™t those monsters in jail? Havenâ€™t they done enough damage to the world?

If I go past 2,000 steps I become hyperactive. I start using energy that doesnâ€™t exist. Then I canâ€™t sleep until 5am that night. Then Iâ€™m up a few hours later starting to struggle. By 3pm Iâ€™m out cold. For the next week I sleep all day and am awake most of the night. Iâ€™m so tired that I can no longer sleep properly. My body aches like Iâ€™ve been in a serious accident. I canâ€™t regulate my temperature. If I stand too long I get light headed. The exhaustion is on my muscles and bones. That week if I push myself at all, I start to slur my words, then fully stutter, then my body starts slowing down finally walking as fast as I can is at a pace 10% that of my normal abilities. My limbs begin to shake. At that point I need to sedate myself. 

Iâ€™m bed bound daily as a prevention.

They do because theyâ€™re not taught otherwise. Thereâ€™s so much evidence proving otherwise but so little funding and research.

Diet is a very popular self treatment method and helps a lot of patients. You also need to have enough energy to prepare nutritious meals. I canâ€™t cook, donâ€™t have the ability to stand that long. But mum makes me soups and I can heat them up. We all work with what we have. Iâ€™m lucky to have my parents caring for me.

I personally can go outside maybe once week and throw the ball for my dogs for about ten minutes. They have to bring it back for me. I canâ€™t go for walks, I need to keep my steps under 2,000 a day or Iâ€™ll suffer severe PEM.

The doctors that believe itâ€™s a mental illness are the worst. Some blamed my weight, I had really bad coping mechanisms (everyone in lockdown can understand now) and got to 300lbs. I was desperate for help so I found an amazing doctor and with his help lost 150lbs in 15mths. My illness is not in my head nor did I do it to myself gaining weight. Iâ€™m as healthy as I can possibly be and fighting as hard as I can. Iâ€™m still stuck in bed 22hrs a day.

Weâ€™re not sure if itâ€™s genetic. No one else in my family is as sick as I am, but I know of families where every generation has a form of ME/CFS.

Mine could be because of the severity of my viral illness, 1 out of 200 people survive the level of sepsis I had. So in a sense Iâ€™m extremely lucky but out of those 1/200 how many fully recover? I have no idea.

Thank you ğŸ’™

It is terrifying and why youâ€™ll find some of us in the wild like here, self advocating. We have a very large online community now and are expecting Covid patients are going to need us to help guide them, which we will do to the best of our ability.

I did, thank you. Iâ€™m in the fb groups, theyâ€™re so helpful with hacks. I actually needed to take a different medication with 8mg of naltrexone for a few months, did nothing for me ME/CFS but made trying LDN at different dosages obsolete. 

Iâ€™m currently trying the Ubiquinol plus antioxidant regimen recommended by a US Immunologist (Iâ€™ll link it, thereâ€™s also a transcript in the comments) and will be doing this a few months more before talking to my doctor about LDN again. Self compounding seems so intimidating! I need to get my head around it x


https://youtu.be/pkGXiJ1jM14
Thank you ğŸ’™
Gotten worse.

Thank you! I developed bad coping mechanisms and then I smashed them.

I have much more pain post weight loss which is the opposite of what my doctors and I expected and itâ€™s complete bullshit ğŸ˜‚

Itâ€™s not my intention to scare but just to inform patients that sometimes there is a third outcome between death and fully recovered. Doctors donâ€™t like to talk about it. 

Some members of the community are going to end up chronically ill, this will impact them for the rest of their lives. Many will be absolutely fine!! 

This community has something ME/CFS sufferers donâ€™t have though, a voice that people are listening to. So when inevitably it is six months from now and some are still unwell, they will need allies to advocate for science and medicine to keep working, keep fighting and finally make that link as to why some of us who suffer a viral infection never recover. Your community may be the key to curing us all. 

So as thrilled as I am that you are feeling better. Donâ€™t forget about those of us who arenâ€™t. And the Covid sufferers who may not. We will need your voice too.

Graded exercise has been found to be harmful for ME sufferers. There was a study called the PACE trial that claimed it was a cure, but years later the results reviewed and found their data fraudulent. Many countries still have clinics that still use it to base their ME/CFS treatments, federal guidelines which have not been updated and doctors in the community who are taught the wrong treatment methods. Itâ€™s hurt so many ME patients. We have a lot of obstacles as sufferers, unfortunately.

Graded exercise is helpful for so many other illnesses though and Iâ€™m very glad you found relief.
Iâ€™m a ME patient giving Covid patients unsolicited medical advice in my original comment. Thereâ€™s no need to be aggressive.

No. Infectious Disease sent my tests country wide to try and find an answer and it was never discovered. â€œUnknown viral infectionâ€ is the best we ever came up with.

Iâ€™ve since seen an Immunologist, Haematologist, Rheumatologist, Endocrinologist and CFS Specialists and no one can find anything.
Iâ€™ve never had mono so canâ€™t personally comment, though many sufferers do say their ME/CFS was triggered by Glandular Fever.

So post ICU your body feels like itâ€™s just survived death and it has. Itâ€™s exhausted. Then that part never quite goes away. Then you find physical activity exacerbates all your symptoms and youâ€™re stuck in this weird limbo of only being able to do 1,500 steps a day. If you go over, everything is so much worse for weeks.

Mentally so many things change too. I canâ€™t concentrate to read books. Iâ€™m not as articulate. I lose my train of thought. Iâ€™m forgetful. 

Over the years symptoms change. Now if I push myself too far my body starts to shut down. It begins with slurred speech and a stutter then my arms and legs will stop working. So when I start to not be able to speak, I treat it as a â€œpanic attackâ€ and sedate myself with Valium. I wake up fine.

I havenâ€™t heard if it. Itâ€™s really unfortunate that we have such small trials and so little funding because science is finding things and making progress, itâ€™s just such a slow process. 

We need an ice bucket challenge level of awareness but we canâ€™t do it because weâ€™re all stuck in bed. 

Also, a lot of sufferers the past year since the star of Unrest (a Netflix documentary about ME/CFS) found her own â€œcureâ€ have discovered itâ€™s an issue with their spinal cord. Theyâ€™re having fusion surgery and the CFS symptoms disappear.

Most days I feel like a healthy person would if they had the flu and had also fallen down a flight of stairs. My body is exhausted in ways words canâ€™t describe. 

But if I push myself and get PEM, I start to slur my words. Then fully stutter. Then I can no longer speak and when I try to walk itâ€™s at 10% my normal pace. My limbs stop working. 

If I donâ€™t rest 22hrs a day and meticulously plan my physical activity, my body shuts down. 

https://www.emerge.org.au/what-is-mecfs
I have parrots! Theyâ€™re my happiness every day and donâ€™t mind that Iâ€™m in bed x

Our local CFS Clinic used a combination of eastern and western medicine. Unfortunately it closed last year after the last real CFS doctor in my city passed away. 
Lots of gut health and supplements. 

Many of us take LDN which is experimental but helps with inflammation, it takes a long time to find the right microdose, I had a reaction last time so will try again at a later date. 

Currently Iâ€™m taking a high antioxidant cocktail that after a few months may increase energy. Iâ€™m very poor but hopeful. Always have to stay optimistic!

I was 26, fully independent, living alone, working full time, very healthy and now Iâ€™m 34 and have been housebound for over 7 years. 

I do get out once a month for appointments and I look the picture of health, you cannot tell Iâ€™m sick, except I slept in preparation the entire week before. I canâ€™t walk far. I canâ€™t stand long. I will overheat very easily. But I hold on to my once a month outings, take a bunch of pain meds, drink my body weight in coffee and endure the week of suffering after. 

ME/CFS doesnâ€™t have a â€œknown causeâ€ generally most of us suffered a viral infection at some point. 

Thereâ€™s a documentary on Netflix called Unrest about us.

The defining characteristic for ME/CFS is Post-exertional malaise (PEM) â€œPost-exertional malaise (PEM) is the worsening of symptoms following even minor physical or mental exertion, with symptoms typically worsening 12 to 48 hours after activity and lasting for days or even weeks.â€

If physical activity was helpful for your body, itâ€™s unlikely that you have ME/CFS. Which is a great thing, hopefully one day youâ€™re diagnosed with something that has a treatment.

All the best.

I truly hope your doctor is correct but unfortunately know that some survivors will end up chronically ill.

Iâ€™m not a Covid survivor. Iâ€™m a viral infection survivor from 2013, who went through multiple organ failure (full renal), septic shock & pneumonia. I was assured a three month full recovery period. Iâ€™m still stuck in bed 22hrs a day and no doctor can find any reason in testing. I have ME/CFS. A diagnosis of exclusion with no treatment. 

The first six months post infection are so important. Be safe, be kind to your bodies and I wish you great health x
Yeah but the inattentive level of these employees is GOT S8 level bad... oh wait.

Tbh sounds even more complicated than BPD (if thatâ€™s possible). 

You have to be able to talk for this to continue. She needs to be able to have a safe word that indicates she needs space when overwhelmed and hopefully begins to trust you more. 

You deserve some stability too x

Nope! Out of sight = abandoned. You push them away, you regret it, you push them away harder you regret it even more but get so worked up about how terrible and useless you are, BPD logic tells you to kill yourself.

If sheâ€™s in treatment and can feel herself becoming obsessed and codependent, maybe thatâ€™s why sheâ€™s asking for space? Therapist recommended for her own sanity. Thatâ€™s rare. 

I canâ€™t really speculate further, the only way youâ€™ll ever know is if she can communicate it with you, which may not be possible.

So she has a deep fear of abandonment and will misinterpret a lot of things you do. â€œIf I leave him he canâ€™t leave meâ€ mentality but she desperately doesnâ€™t want to be alone. Itâ€™s why sheâ€™s hot and cold. Sheâ€™s literally in constant fight of flight mode and I donâ€™t think youâ€™ve seen the worst of it yet. 

Iâ€™m BPD in remission, we do exist. Medication, therapy and accepting that we need to constantly work on ourselves. It can be done.

I donâ€™t know what you should do. Sheâ€™s going to continue to be high maintenance. She needs to comply to treatment to stop the cycle and no one can force her. Itâ€™s a decision she needs to make for herself.

When the ME/CFS community initially saw the pandemic effects we expected the unfortunate climb in covid patients that will inevitably join us in the too hard basket.

It is entirely too soon and you are too unwell to focus on this right now. Eat, drink, sleep and survive. In this monumental task, Iâ€™m sending you strength. 

When you can, find the advocacy groups that already exist. MEAction is big in the UK & America (Emerge in Australia). They already have contacts in government and will know where to send you and your personal advocates to make some noise.

You have all my sympathy and I hope your new issues overnight resolve. You need to see someone about the new symptoms!

I am not a survivor of Covid.

Iâ€™m a survivor of an unknown viral infection that caused multiple organ failure (full renal failure) and septic shock when I too was 26 and in full health.

That was over 7 years ago. 

Iâ€™m still bedbound 22hrs a day and have a diagnosis of ME/CFS. Thereâ€™s no treatment and nothing I can do to improve my health.

Iâ€™m in Australia. I have seen every specialist imaginable. Every doctor is excited to meet me and try and figure out the cause of my illness and each one runs their tests and within a year each admits defeat. Canâ€™t find a thing. 

I hope that you guys are able to find advocates and energised family members to continue this fight. They need to be loud and relentless. Find as much help as you can, you will have limited energy and you need to rest as much as possible. 

The only thing on your side now is that they wonâ€™t be able to deny the ongoing issues when itâ€™s such a large percentage of the population that will be suffering. 

Keep fighting xxx

Once my symptoms settled I was able to reduce to once daily. If I forget one dose, flairs up immediately.

Itâ€™s really common for us to continue to have body image issues during weight loss and even at goal weight. Iâ€™m -150lbs and still see myself as fat. Iâ€™m not. Iâ€™m in a size small. Body dysmorphia is insane.

Looks are deceiving. Iâ€™m so weak now!! All my strength was in my size. We got a new puppy last year and I have to be really careful because heâ€™s almost knocked me on my ass SO many times. My old boy helps me up and down the stairs like a gentleman... but this little asshole ğŸ˜‚

Iâ€™m the opposite. Iâ€™m enjoying maintenance. I heard all the horror stories!

My doctor gave me a threshold of 4.4lbs that my weight is allowed to fluctuate but if I hit that number during weekly weigh ins, I have to get back into the diet. 800 calories and those shakes. The thought of going back on them again makes me feel ill. After 15 months of shakes I NEVER want to do that again. Itâ€™s a powerful motivator!! 

His maintenance calories for me was 1600. I adjusted down 100 as I was slowly gaining, as you do because our bodies are holding onto more fluid now during maintenance. 

I just track everything. If a certain food doesnâ€™t fill me up, then I donâ€™t deem it worthy ongoing. I had hot cross buns recently and they were an old fav but now theyâ€™re just not dense enough to justify the calories, I prefer a fruit English muffin. Or for breakfast I try and have high protein yoghurt with all bran cereal (like a nana) so I hit my fibre for the day early. 

Itâ€™s all about pre planning, experimenting and cutting out the things that donâ€™t really bring you joy. I LOVE fruit juice, itâ€™s my vice. I do not love it enough to waste 200 calories every single day.

I found ways to enjoy everything I love and missed. It just takes a bit of work. 

You also need to weigh every single portion. Itâ€™s a pain but I think itâ€™s the secret.

Ask for professional help. A dietician will reach you to eat healthy. A weight loss doctor (mine was an endocrinologist) will teach you how to lose weight. If it gets hard make another appointment and ask for more help. There are a few medications on the market that can reduce appetite. Itâ€™s not a miracle cure but it gives us a fighting chance. 


Now in the days of isolation going out for appointments is difficult so what I learnt is CICO (calories in vs calories out) is the ONLY scientific way to lose weight. You google your TDEE put in your stats and youâ€™ve got a guide on what calories you can consume to lose weight. 

Then find the weight loss fad diets or â€œthe toolsâ€ that appeal to you. Keto for instance suppresses hunger. IF - intermittent fasting gives you a specific window a day to eat in and is very helpful for structure.

I used all three together. Counted my calories, kept my carbs low (to suppress appetite) and didnâ€™t start eating until late because my craving hit at night. 

Those are all my magic tips. Itâ€™s not easy but it can be done!!!

Congratulations on a strong start!!! 

150 wasnâ€™t a goal I set, it was my doctors. Itâ€™s healthy BMI. It terrified me!! I never imagined getting there, let alone maintaining it. But prior to antidepressants, this was my natural size, right up until my early 20â€™s. I wasnâ€™t a large kid or teen. 

Itâ€™s a nice size. I feel healthy (Iâ€™m not so itâ€™s a start!!). Maintenance calories for me being inactive is 1500, so Iâ€™m not all that restricted. The smaller you get the less you get to eat daily and I missed food so much that I now hit my calories every day with the best foods ğŸ˜

I wish you all the very best! x

My illness was triggered by septic shock, itâ€™s not something that diet can generally touch. 

I do have friends within the ME/CFS community that have tried the various diets, including carnivore, from memory it makes us very sick. Because our cells create so little energy of their own, we generally need carbs. I know that sounds ridiculous after I was low carb for 15 months but I was surviving off fat stores. 

I personally struggle to eat a lot of meat, so it really wouldnâ€™t work for me. The protein part of my Optifast diet was actually the hardest part ğŸ˜‚

My DMs are always a shit show after posting these. Itâ€™s exhausting.

My weight loss doctor is an endocrinologist.
We used Optifast plus protein but also used medications to help with cravings. I took .6mg Saxenda, 25mg Topamax & Contrave. To get me through the 15 months on 800 calories. He didnâ€™t recommended introducing exercise until I was at goal weight and moving to a maintenance diet, I was unable to and thatâ€™s okay. I do what I can. 

I also had severe issues with period. At highest weight we could no longer control it. It wouldnâ€™t stop without medication. I had issues with cysts for years and very heavy flow. 7 days of maternity pad flow. I now have 3-4 day light periods. 

Have a chat with your doctors, chose a low calorie plan and fight!

All the very best xxx
